4.1.5.

Dimensions and Tolerances (Tolerances)

All dimensions have limits of variation, both high and low, that identify the largest and smallest permissible dimension or feature on a part. This difference between the high and low limits on a dimension is called the tolerance. Another way to think of the overall range of acceptable dimensions can be a tolerance band—as used in electronics. Tolerance can affect the size and location dimensions and geometric features such as flatness, parallelism, and others. As a refresher, in lesson 3.2, we defined unilateral tolerance as having +/- dimension, bilateral tolerance as having single side variations, and limit tolerance using specified high/low limits. Along with these international standards, many companies have internal standards that define how their blueprints portray features, dimensions, tolerances, notes, and symbols in conjunction with national or international standards.

Addendum (a)

Is the tooth’s height above the pitch circle. When added to the dedendum, it comprises the whole depth of the tooth.

Base diameter (Db)

Also known as a base circle—lies at the gear tooth base and generates a mathematical notion of involute (an imaginary curved line drawn as if a string was wrapped or unwrapped around the circle).

Circular pitch (p)

Is the measurement of the pitch circle between adjacent teeth on a gear.

Dedendum (b)

Is the depth of a tooth below the pitch circle and is deeper than the opposing gear’s tooth allowing for clearance. When added to the addendum, it comprises the whole depth of the tooth.

Diametral pitch (P)

The relationship of the number of teeth to the pitch diameter shown as a ratio.

Face width (F)

The length of the gear’s teeth measured on an axis. Gear is a machined wheel with protruding teeth that often works ins pairs or series. The term also applies to a working meshed gear set with a larger number of teeth.

Pinion

Is a machined gear with teeth. The term also applies to the gear in a meshing set that has a lesser number of teeth.

Pitch circle

Also known as the pitch line—is the imaginary line midway on a gear’s teeth where an opposing tooth will mesh. It equals the distance from the center of the gear to the pitch point and provides a point for measuring a gear’s speed.

Pitch diameter (D)

Is the diameter of the pitch circle on a line that runs completely through the gear’s center.

Pitch point

Is the point of contact where an opposing pitch circle meshes during the operation of two gears.

Root Diameter (Dr)

Is a circle around the gear laying at the bottom (root) of the gear’s teeth.
